msDesc.head: Collection, made by Nicodemo Tranchedini, of tracts, letters and poems; seven originally separate sections. Italian, c. 1465–70.

supportDesc.support: Paper. Watermarks: cardinal's hat cf. Briquet 3369; flower cf. Briquet 6597; tower cf. Briquet 15911; star in circle cf. Briquet 6068.

handDesc.handNote: seven originally separate sections each by a different scribe

physDesc.additions: Interspersed throughout the book are scribblings and accounts in several hands of the 16th–17th cent. These include (fol. 20) Notes on fractures of the skull; (fol. 21v) Lodovico Ariosto, Orlando Furioso, Canto VII, stanza 18, lines 1–6, followed by a stanza beg: O imagine mia celeste e pura; (fol. 63v) notes for a play or mime on Christ driving the merchants from the temple, of which further pages may have been torn out; (fol. 100) ‘Ad Mortem’ beg: Tu bona, tu immitis Mors es non laudo carentem; (fol. 101) verses beg: Somnia dum profers, ego somnio. Cerno uolantes; (fol. 119) verses beg: Armatam uidit Venarem (sic) Lacedemone Pallas. In the same hand as fol.101, and possibly as fol.21v.

binding.p: Contemporary Italian binding of brown morocco tooled with rope pattern and other designs and with inlet roundels, much repaired. Remains of four leather ties.

history.provenance: On fol.1 are the initials N.TR. in red, on either side of a green laurel wreath containing a shield bearing a double-headed black eagle: these are the arms of Nicodemo Tranchedini of Pontremoli (1411–1481), who for long periods represented the Dukes of Milan as an ambassador, especially in Florence and Rome. For a summary of his career see E. Lazzeroni ‘Il Viaggio di Federico III in Italia’ in R. Dep. Stor. Pat. per la Lombardia, Atti e Memorie del Primo Congresso Storico Lombardo, Milan, 1937, p.327 n.174. He was a close friend of Cosimo de' Medici, was granted Florentine citizenship in 1449 and had a villa at Montughi outside Florence. Several MSS. he once owned bear his arms and initials done in the same style as in our MS.: eg. MSS. Florence Riccard. 541, 827, 834 (Nicodemo's letter book), 873, 1205; Bibl. Nazionale II.X.31, which is a humanistic miscellany in several hands including poems dedicated to Nicodemo; Milan Brera A.H.XII.16.

‘Al molto magnifico et R. sig. mio osservandissimo Il sig. Crispolto Bruschi. Todi’ (fol.132 (flyleaf)): this appears to be in the same hand as the additions on fol.101 and possibly fol.21v and 119. There is a similar note on the first flyleaf, and on fol.119 is written ‘1608 Chrispoltus’ in the same hand as the addition on fol.63v.
history.acquisition: Bought from E. P. Goldschmidt, cat. 19, no. 229, 1929.

recordHist.source: Typescript description by Bodleian Library staff.

msItem.author: Franciscus Philelphus
msItem.title: Letter to Pope Paul II, Sept. 1462
msItem.note: Pr. Epist., Venice, 1502, bk.XXIII, ep.1.

msItem.author: Franciscus Philelphus
msItem.rubric: Eulogium in Pium Secundum ecclesiae romanae pontificem
msItem.incipit: Quo magis ingratus nemo fuit alter: et idem
msItem.note: Pr. in Rosmini, Vita di Francesco Filelfo, Milan, 1808, II p.321. Fol.20v–21v were originally blank.

msItem.author: Pius II
msItem.title: Or. 45 (Ep. 397) 'Cum bellum hodie'
msItem.rubric: Oratio Pii Papę .II. habita in Conventu Mantuano. VI. kl. octobr. Anno domini MCCCCLVIIII
msItem.note: Pr. Aeneae Sylvii Opera, Basle 1571, pp. 905–914. Fol. 36v–37v were originally blank.

msItem.author: Pius II
msItem.title: Letter to Mehmed II
msItem.incipit: Pius Episcopus seruus seruorum dei Illustri Mahumethi Principi turcorum timorem diuini nominis
msItem.note: Mid page 888 of letter as ed. in Opera cit., pp. 872–905; and in a revised edition by G. Toffanin, Pio II, Lettera a Maometto II, Naples 1953, p. 109ff. Fol.63 was originally blank.

msItem.author: Antonius Pellotus
msItem.title: Poems
msItem.note: For Pellotus, a protégé of Nicodemo, see P. O. Kristeller, Studies in Renaissance Thought and Letters, Rome, 1956, p.156. The poems are not rubricated and have no headings. They are perhaps in the hand of Pellotus.
[To his patron, Nicodemo]
msItem.incipit: Virgilius capta patria sibi rure domoque

msItem.note: [To Nicodemo]
msItem.incipit: Quantum coniugio felix Nicodeme domoque

msItem.note: [To Nicodemo]
msItem.incipit: Quantum cyrreus letatur apolline collis
Non minus hospitibus patet hec uenerablis edes
Hac tibi lege meos liceat reprendere uersus
Sepe tuos repetens mecum uir maxime mores

msItem.note: [To Marsilio Ficino]
msItem.incipit: Que nuper digitis ceciderunt carmina nostris
msItem.note: Pr. by Kristeller, loc.cit., from this MS.
[On a visit Conte Jacopo Piccinino made to Cosimo de' Medici at his villa Careggi outside Florence 18 July 1464, for which see Giampietro in Arch. Stor. Prov. Nap. VII, 1882, p.380]
msItem.incipit: Queritis unde mouus fulgenti splendor ab ethra
Ter mihi corue uolans auguria fausta timenti

msItem.note: [To Piero de' Medici on the death of his father, Cosimo, d. Aug. 1464]
msItem.incipit: Quo ferar extremi consumptus tabe doloris

msItem.note: [On Cosimo, Pater Patriae]
msItem.incipit: Pace erat Augustus templis Numa lege Lycurgus

msItem.note: [On Cosimo]
msItem.incipit: Musarum decus egregium et noua gloria cyrre

msItem.note: [To Bartolomeo Scala]
msItem.incipit: Dulce tuum cupidus legi tetrasticon ad me

msItem.note: [On fireworks]
msItem.incipit: Forte Reparate Nicodemus ab dibus ibat

msItem.note: [To Nicodemo]
msItem.incipit: Ultimum uenit Nicodeme tempus

msItem.note: [On Nicodemo's villa]
msItem.incipit: Quos habitare diu cupii saluete penates

msItem.note: [On the plague]
msItem.incipit: Dum mea seretur syrtes uitare malignas

msItem.note: [To Francesco Sassetti, asking for copies of his Priscian, Servius and Pliny's Natural History]
msItem.incipit: Maxime palladie cultor Francisce cohortis

msItem.note: [On the absence of his patron]
msItem.incipit: Ut timet ora lupi pecus una relicta per agros
Sfortigene Nicodeme ducis petis ora beatus
Mustellis crocale blandior omnibus
Quinque ego seruatus parmensis caseus annos

msItem.note: [On the too long absence of Nicodemo]
msItem.incipit: Qui sine te inuitus uitales concipit auras

msItem.note: [A plea to Nicodemo to return to Montughi]
msItem.incipit: Si colis illius flicia numina supplex
Gratus eram quondam cybeli cybeleius atis

msItem.note: [To Lorenzo de' Medici on his going to Rome, probably in March 1465]
msItem.incipit: Viderat arquitenens arcum pharetramque uolucris

msItem.note: [To Nicodemo]
msItem.incipit: Has ne uides caueis tectas Nicodeme uolucres

msItem.note: [To Ficino]
msItem.incipit: Si quisquam est cui me fatear debere Ficine
msItem.note: Pr. Kristeller, loc. cit., p.157, from this MS.

msItem.incipit: Hunc sibi seruat Hymen lectum: temerare caueto

msItem.note: [To Don Federico, son of King Ferrante of Naples, probably when he stayed in Florence June 22–7 1465 while escorting his brother's bride, Ippolita Sforza, to Naples]
msItem.incipit: Frondibus unde nouis uario discrimine uocum

msItem.note: [To the Duke of Melfi who accompanied Don Federico]
msItem.incipit: Ille uetus quondam Mecenas splendor equestris
Me mea rimosum Daris [?] iracunda uocauit

msItem.note: [To Nicodemo]
msItem.incipit: Ite procul muse si nil mihi carmina prosunt
Aspice quisquis ades niue miracula dextr
Si duo prima magis gentile carmina constant

msItem.note: [To the Greek poet Marullo?]
msItem.incipit: M arule quem παντων charis alma φιλοτερον ὑιον
Rubescant quamuis circum tua tempora cani
Clam loqueris multis pellotum quod facis hecte

msItem.note: Fol.75v, 77, 81, 82v–84v were originally left blank.

msItem.author: Antonio Geraldini
msItem.title: Poems
msItem.rubric: Antonii Geraldini Amerini liber carminum Ad Magnificum Petrum Medicem Florentinum optimatem de Re. P. Flo. B. M.
msItem.note: Geraldini (c.1453–1489) probably wrote these poems when he was in Florence as a young man, before he went to Spain in 1469. See Kristeller, loc. cit., p.155

msItem.incipit: Ipse grandaeuum Cytherea proles
msItem.note: Written after the death of Cosimo de' Medici, 1464

msItem.rubric: Ad diuam Virginem Mariam quae Florentiae Nuntiata nuncupatur
msItem.incipit: Aeterna o genitrix regis olympici

msItem.rubric: Ad diuam Virginem Mariam quae Florentiae nuntiata cognominatur
msItem.incipit: Angeli mira nitidi salute

msItem.rubric: Ad Marsilium Florentinum philosophum platonicum clarissimum
msItem.incipit: Rugas pone tua fronte seuerior
msItem.note: pr. Kristeller, loc. cit., p.157 from this MS.

msItem.rubric: Ad Ginum Coponem (sic) ciuem Florentinum de se B. M.
msItem.incipit: Maxima Gine tuo cepi solatia rure

msItem.rubric: Ad Antonium Posbonellum virum ingenui studii peritissimum
msItem.incipit: Lutheo stratis roseis amictu

msItem.rubric: Ad Antonium Posbonellum insubrem virum ingenuum
msItem.incipit: O fax insubriae micans amoenae

msItem.rubric: Ad Eundem Antonium
msItem.incipit: Antoni aonium decus

msItem.rubric: Ad Gentilem Urbinatem uirum ingenuum epigrammatumque scriptorem
msItem.incipit: Pomiferis autumnus agris sibi pampinus corona

msItem.rubric: Ad Bartholomaeum Scalam rei publicae Florentinae scribam peritissimum
msItem.incipit: Nunc te diua precor cape Polymnia
msItem.note: Scala was Chancellor of Florence by April 1465, and possibly earlier

msItem.rubric: Ad Magnificum Petrum Medicem Florentinum optimatem de re P.B.M
msItem.incipit: Lydiae gentis Medices columna

msItem.rubric: Magnifico uiro Petro Medici Florentino optimati de Patria B.M.
msItem.incipit: Iam tandem optatos iterum spectamus hetruscos

msItem.rubric: Magnifico uiro Laurentio Medici Florentino primati
msItem.incipit: Mirifico luxu ualuis sublimis apertis

summary.p: Poems and extracts probably in the hand of Pompeius Bononiensis, who apparently lived in Rome, including some of his own poems and a copy of a letter written by him in Naples in 1465

msItem.rubric: Epigramma apud Aquileiam Antiquissimam Italie
Epigramma apud Beneventum in quodam arcu triumphali pulchritudinis admirande ubi dicitur porta aurea
In eadem urbe in basi unius domus
msItem.note: C.I.L. IX. 1575. This copy may be earlier than any of those cited there

msItem.rubric: Epigramma ad ęneam [Alexandri] statuam inspicientem celum et quantulumque solo incumbentem ex phida fabrissculptore perinclyto
msItem.note: Two lines of a Greek poem (Anthologia Graeca XVI, 120) written as an inscription, deriving in this form from Ciriaco of Ancona. See E. W. Bodnar, Cyriacus of Ancona and Athens, Brussels, 1960, p.156

msItem.rubric: In quodam Virgilio antiquissimo Octauio Caesari
msItem.incipit: Temporibus letis tristis mihi maxime Caesar
msItem.note: Reise, Anthol. Lat., no.242

msItem.rubric: Ouidius
msItem.incipit: Virgilius magno quantum concessit Homero
msItem.note: Reise, Anthol. Lat. no.1

msItem.title: Collection of epitaphs on Virgil
msItem.rubric: In quodam [codice] antiquissimo inuenta
msItem.incipit: Mantua me genuit Calabri rapuere tenet nunc (first epitaph)
msItem.note: WIC 10656. The others in series as in Reise, Anthol. Lat., nos.507–518; one also in Walther, no.19305

msItem.rubric: Item de titulo Virgilii quatuor uersibus
msItem.note: Reise, Anthol. Lat., nos.555–565

msItem.title: Note on Cicero
msItem.note: Fragment, cut off at the top, followed by a few words of a Greek-Latin glossary

msItem.title: Inscription
msItem.rubric: Versus in lapide antiquissimo Rom reperti Epitaphium Galb palatini
msItem.incipit: Ad lapidem profectus erat uix Galba Secundum

msItem.author: Ausonius
msItem.title: Epigr. III (X)
msItem.rubric: Galli epigramma
msItem.incipit: Toxica Zelotipo dedit uxor moecha marito

msItem.rubric: Pro Diua Hyppolita filia Francisci Sforci Pompeius Bononiensis
msItem.incipit: Quisquis in Hyppolita miratur lumina diua
msItem.explicit: Huius ad aeternum fama perennis eat. / Finis Hyppolite Filio Alfonso Ferdinandi Regis nuptę
msItem.note: Hippolita Sforza, bride of Alfonso Duke of Calabria, arrived in Naples on 14 Sept. 1465. See Canetta in Arch. Stor. Lombardo X, 1883, p.780

msItem.rubric: Ad Diuam Lucretiam Alfonsi Regis Amicam Pompeius Bononiensis
msItem.incipit: Maxima pars nostrę cum sis Lucretia curę
msItem.note: Lucrezia d'Alagno, mistress of King Alfonso I of Naples (d.1458) was in Ravenna, where the poet states her to be, by the end of 1464. See Filangieri in Arch. Stor. Prov. Nap. XI, 1886, p.359

msItem.rubric: Epitaphium Iacobi Picenini
msItem.incipit: Desine non notum Picenini querere fatum
msItem.note: Conte Jacopo Piceinino, who died mysteriously in prison in Naples 12 July 1465

msItem.rubric: Divo Ferdinando Regi Pompeius Bononiensis de eius laudibus
msItem.incipit: Si uacat o princeps magnarum maxime rerum
msItem.note: The poet refers (fol.108) to the preparations the king is making for his son's marriage. See fol. 103 above

msItem.rubric: Pro Porcellio nummis exhausto
msItem.incipit: Quis neget hunc magnum uel non putet esse poetam
msItem.note: The poet Porcellio Pandoni was teaching in the Studio at Naples in mid 1465–6. See Percopo, in Arch. Stor. Prov. Nap. XX, 1895, p.320

msItem.rubric: De pontifice Calisto et Pio et Paulo
msItem.incipit: Barbarie dederat nobis mala secla Calistus

msItem.rubric: De pontificum temporibus
msItem.incipit: Aurea Roma fuit Nicolai tempore diui

msItem.rubric: De puella picta
msItem.incipit: Alter in hac tabula verus me pinxit apelles

msItem.rubric: Quid placeat plus an Roma an Parthenope
msItem.incipit: Parthenope fueram Romę fueramus et una

msItem.rubric: Ad Iulium: Pom.
msItem.incipit: Hic adeo Iuli recitant epigrammata uates
msItem.note: The end of the poem has been cut off by the binder

msItem.author: Pompeius Bononiensis
msItem.title: Letter
msItem.incipit: Quamquam his diebus elapsis nullas ad te litteras dederim
msItem.note: Copy of a letter from Pompeius Bononiensis [in Naples] to Paulus Vannus [in Rome]. The writer describes recent entertainments arranged by King Ferrante, probably for Ippolita Sforza, who attended them, discusses the mysterious death of Jacopo Piccinino, and asks his friend to look after his books until his return

msItem.rubric: Idem Pompeius pro quadam puella in puero acensa
msItem.incipit: Candide me placida nolis incendere forma

msItem.rubric: Contra Succam
msItem.incipit: Priscus erat puero contentus Iupiter uno

msItem.rubric: Pro Aenea
msItem.incipit: Torqueor Aene uates miserabilis igne

msItem.rubric: Ad laudem Pauli pont. max. Pompeius Bononiensis
msItem.incipit: Magna Pii fuerant: Pauli maiora secundi
msItem.note: Pope Paul II, elected Aug. 1464, d.July 1471

msItem.rubric: De Amore Primo
msItem.incipit: Armatum telis primus qui nouit amorem

msItem.note: Fragment.
msItem.rubric: Addere materia conueniente modis
msItem.incipit: Arma graui numero uiolentaque bella parabam

msItem.rubric: Libros quos Rome habeo
msItem.note: A list of classical authors. Further books are listed below and on fol.118v, with the names of the people who have borrowed them: these include Antonello [Petrucci] secretary of the King of Naples and Antonio Rossi of Florence, secretary to the Cardinal of Spoleto. The writer was also having Ovid's Fasti copied by the scribe Giovan M[arco Cinico] of Parma. Fol.100v–102v, 117 were originally left blank

msItem.author: Gentile Becchi
msItem.title: Poems
msItem.note: Collection of poems by Gentile Becchi of Urbino, tutor to Lorenzo de' Medici, cr. bishop of Arezzo 1473, d.1497. The poems, possibly dedicated to Iacopo Ammanati, Cardinal of Pavia, all seem to have been written in the 1460's. Fol.119 was originally blank, apart from the heading ‘Gentiles’. Fol.120 is also headed ‘Gentiles’.

msItem.rubric: Cur hoc Volumine
msItem.incipit: Hac nunc te volo mi libelle forma

msItem.rubric: Quod Amor amantem amare compulerit
msItem.incipit: Cecus amor domuit numerosi luminis argum

msItem.rubric: Quod iussu Cosmi Villicus duobus trabem bobus traxit quam uix quattuor ante mouerat
msItem.incipit: Quam modo uix poterant siluis auellere quercum

msItem.rubric: Sub statua Iudith Leofernem interimentis sub pedibusque bracchia quedam prementis
msItem.incipit: Regna cadunt luxu surgunt uirtutibus urbes

msItem.rubric: Dimittens Laurentium meum quem ab adolescentia institueram
msItem.incipit: Laurenti quaecumque tuos fortuna uolatus

msItem.rubric: In Aquilinum qui moderna non quia mala sed quia non antiqua improbabat
msItem.incipit: Qui solos ueteres amas poetas

msItem.rubric: De quadrireme quam Pio pontifici Florentini dederunt ad cuius fabricam videram per arnum materiam sine ductore labi illique fabrum quattuor pro tribus aptare remos
msItem.incipit: Mirabar solas ageret quis flumine pinus

msItem.rubric: Nomen quadriremis Victoria alludens ad patris Siluii matrisque Victorie nomina
msItem.incipit: Siluius ante parens ero nunc Victoria mater

msItem.rubric: In scriptum signo pacis quod Anuntiare rex Francie dederat ex voto
msItem.incipit: Cum simul in populos pacis sanctissima virgo

msItem.rubric: Quod casus tabule quam crus fregisse Ia. Picinino dicebant illum claudum ad patrem Nicolaum claudum demiserit
msItem.incipit: Omnis cum modo diceret corona
msItem.note: For Piccinino's death see fol.107

msItem.rubric: Dum referretur Habrahe sacrificium in quo Isahac personam puer agebat quem Antonius pedico deperibat
msItem.incipit: Crudelis genitor genito iam parce cruori

msItem.rubric: Dum mihi in munus aureum Vopisco togam ille multis ego paucis gratias egeram
msItem.incipit: Si mea musa minor uideatur Cosme Vopisca
msItem.note: Vopiscus was Bartolomeo Scala, protégé of the Medici and Chancellor of Florence from c.1465

msItem.rubric: In promotione Caroli de Medicis ad ecclesiam pratensem
msItem.incipit: Quam male prata carent pastoribus et grege campi
msItem.note: Carlo de' Medici became Provost of Prato in Aug.1460. See Pieraccini, La Stirpe dei Medici di Cafaggiolo, Florence, 1924, I.90

msItem.rubric: In Laurenti portu ad arni hostia
msItem.incipit: Quo deę quonam fluviales itis

msItem.rubric: Cur non ederet de anima Landinus ad Ficianum excusatio
msItem.incipit: Edere vis animam Landinum Phiciniane

msItem.rubric: Post titulum sepulti
msItem.incipit: Salue care pater cineres saluete parentis

msItem.rubric: Ad Petrum Alamannum qui non exscribenda sed scripta epigrammata petebat
msItem.incipit: Scis uersus tibi cur meos negarim

msItem.rubric: Quot voluptates Ro. Martellus dicebat se in Florentino templo captare
msItem.incipit: Hinc oculos Roberte tibi lasciua puella
msItem.note: Roberto Martelli died in January 1463/4. See Arch. di Stato, Florence, Grascia Morti 5, fol.44v

msItem.rubric: Mittens candelam benedictam Iuliano post dimissionem Leurentii
msItem.incipit: I. nostro mea musa Scipioni

msItem.rubric: Excusatio de his que dabantur vicio Pio pon[tifici (?)]
msItem.incipit: Queritis unde Pio placeant nemus arma penates

msItem.rubric: Laus Cosmi ex invectiva Philelphi
msItem.incipit: Sunt qui te primum patrie dixere parentem
msItem.note: Two other versions of this poem exist, in MS. Florence Laur.54.10, Scala's Collectiones Cosmianae, fol.153 and MS. Laur.90 sup.39 fol.30. The last two lines of all three are different. See Bandini, Cat. Codd. Lat. Bibl. Laur. II, col.650; III, col.552

msItem.rubric: Cum primum coram Galeatio postea Ipolite et Sfortia fratre Florentini leones nihil uenationis edidissent excusatio
msItem.incipit: Parcite Sfortiade solitus si frangere tauros
msItem.note: On the failure of the lion hunt arranged for Ippolita Sforza: see letter of Marco Parenti, 22–7 June 1465, pr. Guasti, Lettere di una Gentildonna Fiorentina, Florence, 1877, p.432

msItem.rubric: Ad Reverendissimum Cardinalem Papiensem de his libellis in laudem Campani
msItem.incipit: Non dum sat tibi fecimus Papia
msItem.note: The Cardinal of Pavia was Jacopo Ammanati, cr. 1461, d.1479

msItem.rubric: Cur potius Papia alii Papiensis
msItem.incipit: Cur reliquis Papiensis ais mihi sisque Papia

msItem.rubric: Laus Peregrini Allii ex nominibus in quosdam suos uersus ad Cos.
msItem.incipit: Hec peregrina neget siquis malus esse latina
msItem.note: Pellegrino Allio (1440– c.1467–8) was in Florence in 1463–4 and then went to Rome. See Flamini, Pellegrino Allio, Pisa, 1893

msItem.rubric: Ad Franciam canonicatum querentem
msItem.incipit: Tu quoque caprinas sumis nunc Francia vestes

msItem.rubric: Epithaphium Siciliani equi in littore Pisano sepulti quem dono Laurens erat habiturus
msItem.incipit: Quos fremitus sentis pelagi ne crede viator

msItem.rubric: In ortis Cosmianis sub statua cuiusdam gerentis capite poma cum obducta circum pudibunda veste
msItem.incipit: Quidnam quid rapis o puella furax

msItem.rubric: Cauendum ne quid amplius petam
msItem.incipit: Sum tribus in lustris dominum tria dona precatus

msItem.rubric: E Platone de stella suo dum viueret
msItem.incipit: Stellas stella polo meditaris pluribus vt te

msItem.rubric: Mortuo
msItem.incipit: Stella prius fueras eris et nunc lucifer ante

msItem.rubric: Ut benefitium quod cum cura uacabat consequerer
msItem.incipit: Es petrus et pelago mittentem retia Petrum
msItem.note: This poem, addressed to Piero de' Medici, is also in MS. Florence B.N. II.X.31, fol.166v

msItem.rubric: Ad Nicodemum Tranchedinum
msItem.incipit: Vis dicam tibi Nicodeme quare

msItem.rubric: Mittens Varonem de origine lingue latine ad Peregrinum Alludens ad nomina [i.e. to Pellegrino Allio]
msItem.incipit: Pyerios quamuis saltus peragraueris omnes

msItem.rubric: Pro Epythaphio Cosmi
msItem.incipit: Clauditur hoc magnus Medices sub marmore Cosmus
msItem.note: Cosimo died 1 Aug. 1464

msItem.rubric: Ex aditu Lucretie ad balnea aque lex
msItem.incipit: Parcite mortales nec tu nisi tempore certo
msItem.note: The poem probably concerns Lucrezia Tornabuoni, wife of Piero de' Medici

msItem.rubric: Dum edificaret Carolus exceperat domi Hieronymum laborantem morbo calculorum quos ille marmora appellabat
msItem.incipit: Carole iam poterunt Veios migrare quirites

msItem.rubric: Sub statua Dauid ceso Gulia in arca Cosmiana ad animandos pro patria ciues
msItem.incipit: Victor est quisquis petriam tuetur

msItem.rubric: De seditione Florentina quae in nuptias Jo. Tornaboni affinis Petri de Medicis sumpta filia Luce Pithii qui diuerse factionis princeps extiterat finiit
msItem.incipit: Quis finis tandem fuerit ciuilibus armis
msItem.note: Giovanni Tornabuoni married Francesca, daughter of Luca Pitti, in 1466

msItem.rubric: Mittens imaginem Cosmianam in sulphure excusatio materie
msItem.incipit: Si caput inuictum fragili de sulphure princeps

msItem.rubric: Ad limen Laurentis templi
msItem.incipit: Sacra sumus Veneres Laurentis limina templi

msItem.rubric: Mittens vitulam in festo die sancte Cecilię cuius plebem in ciuili victoria fueram consecutus. Ediderat autem iisdem ferme diebus Vitellus quidam versus de gemma arbore pro Cosmo secundam pro Petro fingens ad P. Med.
msItem.incipit: Tam gratus tibi si fuit Vitellus

msItem.rubric: Obierat Iohanni de Medicis filius Cosmus nomine. Obiit et Petro Francisco alius eiusdem nominis. Monendum censui ne amplius illi parem aliquem facerent quem etiam nomine solum esse fata uoluissent
msItem.incipit: Parcite iam Medices Cosmi deducere nomen

msItem.rubric: Ad Anuntiatam dum mercatores quorum insigne aquila aurea est ad illius curam sumendam accederent
msItem.incipit: Virgo precipuum numen Etrurię

msItem.rubric: Ad Cosmianum sacellum in cuius prima parto Magi in secunda angeli canentes in tertia Maria partum adorans ut corde uerbo et opere adeuntes sacrificarent pingebatur
msItem.incipit: Regum dona preces superum. Mens Virginis arę

msItem.rubric: Ad marmorariam tabernam dum Carolus Aretinus sculperetur
msItem.incipit: Quem modo formari spectas de marmore uatem
msItem.note: Carlo Marsuppini died in 1453. His tomb was sculpted by Desiderio da Settignano, d.1464

msItem.rubric: Mortuo Cosmo ostendit ciuitas quid illi obierit. Docoxere enim plures quod cum uerius uiri laudem exprimeret quam statua quam decreuerant hoc ad Io. et B. dysticon
msItem.incipit: Vidistis ne patres qualem Florentia Cosmo

msItem.rubric: Ad hostium librarię taberne Vespatiani
msItem.incipit: Quisquis es ista priusquam limina nosce Viator
msItem.note: On the shop of the bookseller Vespasiano da Bisticci

msItem.rubric: Cum aliquem ex Florentinis Pontifex peteret cum quo tractaret de pace missus est Otho Nicolinus cui alterum deerat brachium
msItem.incipit: Quam cupit hinc uideas pastor Florentia pacem
msItem.note: Probably on Otto Niccolini's mission to Rome in 1467/8

msItem.rubric: Cur tam crebre decoctiones fierent
msItem.incipit: Bella senex.pacem iuvenis. Pius arma.Quietem

msItem.rubric: Cum sine militaribus signis in Florentinos Colio arma mouisset tuereturque se menibus Fauentinis de peste quae exercitum inuaserat
msItem.incipit: Perdere ne posset Colio sua signa reliquit
msItem.note: The condottiere Bartolomeo Colleoni prepared to attack the Florentines in the spring of 1467

msItem.rubric: Discedens Florentia Roman Carolus de Borboni qui in conuiuio pomum aureum Lucretie indignanti Marie dixit se loco illius cor relinquere
msItem.incipit: Quanuis sic niueo sinu fouetur
msItem.note: Charles de Bourbon, Archbishop of Lyons, was sent to Rome as envoy of the King of France in October 1466

msItem.rubric: Ad L. unde illi uxor ducenda
msItem.incipit: Gallia si Italie ceruix si Tuscia pectus
msItem.note: Probably to Lorenzo de' Medici; the negotiations for his marriage to Clarice Orsini began early in 1467

msItem.rubric: Sub imagine Danthis
msItem.incipit: Cum patriam Danthes anime tres morte recessus

msItem.rubric: Hieronymus Ranucius medicus bononiensis sepius mihi per iocum illud Platinensis retulerat. Coram dicere pontifice. Accessit non multo post orator sue patrie quae cum esset suspecta pontifici monui ne in omnibus Platinam uellet referre qui male orando passus fuerat carceres Adriane arcis
msItem.incipit: Non satis est Platinam uerbis retulisse Ranuci
msItem.note: Platina was imprisoned in 1464 by Pope Paul II for his outspokenness

msItem.rubric: Dum ponuntur porte Laurentis templi ex aere nuper in etruria invento
msItem.incipit: Diue quem templi colit ara maior

msItem.rubric: Sub imagine Giannotii aurati et laureati
msItem.incipit: Esset ut ante oculos uite melioris imago
msItem.note: On the humanist and statesman Giannozzo Manetti, d.1459

msItem.rubric: De sepulchro Laurentii de Medicis quod esset in Laurenti templo et utrinque patens
msItem.incipit: Quam bene Laurenti Medices Laurentia templa
msItem.note: Lorenzo, brother of Cosimo de' Medici, died in 1440

msItem.rubric: In aulum
msItem.incipit: Qui cena tibi factus est amicus

msItem.rubric: Sub imagine diui Laurentii
msItem.incipit: Sum Laurens mihi castus amor mihi laurea palma

msItem.rubric: Victo Hercule Estense dum sub Colione militaret
msItem.incipit: Hercule sub lato queris clauaque relicta
msItem.note: Ercole d'Este was badly wounded at the battle called ‘della Molinella’, July 1467

msItem.rubric: Franciscus Norus Antonio patri sepulchrum posuerat ac super statuam gestantem capite aquam benedictam hocque Epythaphium manibus tenentem
msItem.incipit: Hos quisquis latices petis Viator

msItem.rubric: Prope Saluianum templum rem agenti cum uxore uillico in scrobe quam fodiebat ita egesta tellus superruit ut pene abruti sint
msItem.incipit: Dum fodis uxorem pro terra villice parce

msItem.rubric: Sub uersibus Platinensis quos in laudem Reverendissimi domini Papiensis ineptius ediderat quam soleret alludens simul ad id quod cum nescisset prius coram pontifice fingere fuerat missus in carcerem
msItem.incipit: Ex me cum modo quererent sodales

msItem.rubric: Cur Florentinorum arma in nuptias desierint
msItem.incipit: Mars Veneris quondam fuit et Florentia Martis

msItem.rubric: Quod iussum dystichon de chyrotecis amissis amiseram
msItem.incipit: Quod rem uersus agit preter uada feruida uexi

msItem.rubric: Epythaphium Marci hystrionis Pisani
msItem.incipit: Pisarum lachrimę prius uoluptas

msItem.rubric: Pro Papiensi ad Campanum
msItem.incipit: Auspiciis Liuii quamuis superauerat hostem
msItem.note: To Giannantonio Campano 1429–1477

msItem.rubric: Excusatio quod in quodam ad Reverendissimum d. Papiensem uersu “ras” syllabam producendam breuem posueram
msItem.incipit: Ras breue quod posui miraris maxime princeps

msItem.rubric: Ad hoc ipsum Volumen in Anticatonis formam
msItem.incipit: Quo nam quo propera rudis libelle
msItem.explicit: Ne senam oneo petas libelle. / Finis.
msItem.note: To the Cardinal of Pavia.

revisionDesc.change: James Cummings Up-converted the markup using https://github.com/jamescummings/Bodleian-msDesc-ODD/blob/master/convertTolkien2Bodley.xsl
